items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Traci Williams, Principal, Piedmont Hills High School
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Request for a One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to Allow for a Fireworks Display at Piedmont Hills High School on October 2, 2015
	 
	 
On behalf of the Associated Student Body (ASB):
Richard Nguyen, ASB President
Rita Chang, ASB Vice President
Sydnie Tanujaya, ASB Secretary
Tina Tran, ASB Treasurer
	 
The student's of Piedmont Hills High School are requesting the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis.  This display is for the homecoming game and the school's 50th anniversary celebration.
	 
Board Policy 5142.1 prohibits the following at the sites and on District facilities: (1) open fires including Bon Fires of any type; (2) pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) explosive devices, such as firecrackers.  A one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 has allowed for planned fireworks/pyrotechnics displays for special celebrations, such as, homecoming games or school anniversaries.
	 
Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:
This is a one-time waiver only.
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one week before the planned event.
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event  (including, but not limited to, an endorsement naming the District as a additional insured), to be determined by the Administration, to be provided at least one business day before the planned event.
The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.
The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event.
No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.
The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus, including, but not limited to, the athletic and activities fields.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Associated Student Body (ASB) Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Piedmont Hills High School, subject to the conditions as presented and the approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Piedmont Hills High School, subject to the conditions as presented and the approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Lauren Kelly, Principal, and Virginia Yenter Yanowsky, Activities Director, Evergreen Valley High School
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Use of Carnival Equipment at Evergreen Valley High School for Homecoming Celebration and Multi-Cultural Winterfest 
	 
On behalf of the Associated Student Body (ASB):
Mindy Tran, ASB President
Sandhya Lyer, ASB Vice President
Kushal Sharma, ASB Secretary
Puneet Cheema, ASB Treasurer
Max Navarro, Director of Publicity and Marketing
Maharshi Patel, Inter Club Council Commissioner
Students of Evergreen Valley High School are requesting the approval for the use of rental carnival equipment for their Homecoming Celebration and their Multi-Cultural Winterfest. 
	 
Homecoming Tailgate Celebration is scheduled on November 6, 2015.  Evergreen Valley H.S. is requesting the rental of interactive games to add to the fun and excitement of the event.  ASB is paying for the rentals; teachers and administration will be present throughout the entire event.  Games may include: Double High Striker, Jacobs Ladder, One Arm Bandit Money Machine, and the Bullseye Archery.   
	 
Multi-Cultural Winterfest is scheduled for December 5, 2015. Evergreen Valley H.S. is requesting the rental of a Ferris Wheel for their annual Multi-Cultural Winterfest celebration.  On the first Friday of December the school site will open the campus to the community and provide a winter holiday festival complete with performances by the clubs and community, music, food, crafts and games will add to the excitement. 
	 
Administration recommends Board approval on the following conditions:
The school and rental companies provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate permits, insurances, licenses, etc. no later than one week before the planned event.
The equipment and/or rides shall be placed in a safe area.
The school shall obtain adequate security and staff personnel on site during the scheduled events.
The rental companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus including but not limited to the athletic and activities fields.
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Associated Student Body (ASB) Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for the use/rental of the requested carnival equipment subject to the conditions as presented.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for the use/rental of the requested carnival equipment subject to the conditions as presented.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.06 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, April Chou, Director of Operations, KIPP Bay Area Schools, and Adam Kaye, Director of Real Estate
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Proposed Ground Lease Agreement with KIPP Bay Area Schools for Prop. 39
	 
The District is the chartering authority for KIPP San Jose Collegiate public charter school operated by KIPP: Bay Area Schools.  
	 
Education Code section 47614(b) provides in part: 
	 
“Each school district shall make available, to each charter school operating in the school district, facilities sufficient for the charter school to accommodate all of the charter school’s in-district students in conditions reasonably equivalent to those in which the students would be accommodated if they were attending other public schools of the district.”
	 
The implementing regulations for Section 47614 are contained in Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations, section 11969.1 – 11969.11.  Section 11969.1(b) of the Regulations provides:
	 
“If a charter school and a school district mutually agree to an alternative to specific compliance with any of the provisions of this article, nothing in this article shall prohibit implementation of that alternative, including, for example, funding in lieu of facilities in an amount commensurate with local rental or lease costs for facilities reasonably equivalent to facilities of the district.”
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39 the District has provided facilities to KIPP pursuant to a Facilities Use Agreement for the period July 2013 through June 2017.  Pursuant to the Facilities Agreement KIPP currently pays approximately $103,000 annually in pro rata charges and excess space charges to the District for 24,960 square feet of improved existing classroom and office/administrative space and shared use of the District’s facilities and outdoor athletic facilities.
	 
KIPP has proposed to enter into a long term lease agreement with the District for 2.36 acres (103,000 square feet) of land at the Independence High School site to meet KIPP San Jose Collegiate’s Prop. 39 facilities needs on a long term basis.  Under such an arrangement KIPP would construct its own school facilities on the land for use as KIPP’s charter school facilities.  
	 
The District and KIPP have been working towards and have made substantial progress on a formal written agreement for consideration and approval by the Board.  Administration anticipates such agreement will be presented to the Board for consideration and approval at the October regular Board meeting.  Currently, the key terms of the proposed agreement are as follows:
KIPP would construct a school facility of approximately 40,000 – 60,000 square feet on the site for KIPP’s grade 9-12 program which would include approximately 30 classrooms for core academic classes including science labs and special education rooms, 5 enrichment spaces, including art rooms, and a media center/library, and ancillary administration and faculty offices, student services and custodial spaces and related site improvements and utility installations.
The District will continue to share outdoor athletic facilities (e.g., fields, track, hard court surfaces, etc.) with KIPP for KIPP’s physical education classes/program.
The use of the premises and facilities would be limited to a public charter high school serving grades 9-12.
The facilities design and construction shall be to the same building and safety standards for public classroom facilities and will be subject to review and approval of the Division of the State Architect (DSA).
The agreement would be for a term of thirty (30) years with three options to renew the term for 5 years each (total possible lease term of 45 years).
KIPP shall pay rent to the District of $1.00 per square foot per year (approx. $103,000 per year) in lieu of its pro rata facilities share under Prop. 39 and KIPP shall pay its own utilities and operating expenses and shall be responsible for maintaining and repairing the facility and improvements.
So long as the lease is in effect KIPP will not seek or have the right to obtain additional facilities from the District pursuant to Proposition 39 for KIPP San Jose Collegiate charter school.
At the end of the lease term title in all facilities built by KIPP will vest in the District.
The parties are discussing a possible contribution of $1,400,000 by the District towards the planned KIPP gymnasium in exchange for shared use of the KIPP gymnasium by up to two (2) other charter schools on the Independence site for up to a total of four hours per school day (2 hours during instructional time, 2 hours before or after school).
	 
Funding Source:
Not applicable at this time.
	 
Fiscal Impact:
To be determined.
	 
Recommendation: 
Not action requested; informational only at this time.

Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-05 Establishing Appropriations GANN Spending Limit  
					 
					 
The GANN amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the amendment must calculate their appropriations limit for the coming year.  There is no direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the GANN limitation and other 2015/2016 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with proceeds of taxes. 
					 
The attached Resolution is being presented for adoption.
					 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
					 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
					 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2015/2016-05 establishing appropriations for the GANN Spending Limit.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public hearing at Approximately 6:40 p.m. for Resolution #2015/2016-06 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119
	 
BACKGROUND
Education Code Section 60119 requires that local Board of Education hold a public hearing and declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks and standards.  If the Governing Board finds an insufficiency, it must make known to the public the reasons for the insufficiency and take action to ensure that the situation is remedied within eight weeks from the start of school.  This public hearing is intended to comply with the regulation.
	 
Please be advised that the present California State per pupil allocation for the purchase of instructional materials is sufficient to provide each student with instructional support materials for each class for school year 2015-2016.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Administration recommends that the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2015/2016-06 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119, and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 17, 2015, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.
items.item_recommendation: The Administration recommends that the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2015/2016-06 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials per Education Code 60119, and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 17, 2015, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-06 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials
	 
BACKGROUND
In 2000, a class action lawsuit was filed claiming that some public schools were failing to provide students with equal access to instructional materials, safe and decent school facilities, and qualified teachers.  In 2004, the case was settled and required school districts to ensure that all students had access to the approved instructional supplies (textbooks). Governing Boards are required to hold a public hearing.
	 
For ESUHSD, the schools that are visited are Andrew Hill, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove, W.C.Overfelt, and Yerba Buena. The Santa Clara County has certified that each of the six schools have met the "Sufficiency of Textbooks" requirement.  The certification for the schools that are not visited is done by the Principal.  Each Principal, for the non-visited schools submits a signed "Certification of Textbook Sufficiency".
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees to adopt Resolution #2015/2016-06 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials.

Any person may address the Board on any item on the meeting agenda.  Persons wishing to address the Board must fill out a gold request form, which is located at the entrance of the  Board Room. When your name is called, please come to the podium, state your name for the record, and limit your remarks to three (3) minutes.

Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Accept the Unaudited Actual Financial Report for Fiscal Year 2014/2015
	 
	 
Attached for your review is a copy of the 2014-15 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.  The report provides a detailed summary of the District's fiscal status as of June 30, 2015.  Your approval is required to certify the 2014-15 unaudited actual financial report as required by Education Code 42100.  In addition, your approval will establish appropriations to account for differences between the estimated year-end balances and the unaudited year-end balances as required by Education Code 42600 prior to submission to the County Office of Education and the State.
	 
INCLUDED:
A SACS book detailing General Fund revenue and expenses for fiscal year 2014-15 estimated actual vs. 2014-15 unaudited actual.  Also included are detailed summary information highlighting the same type of information for each fund including special revenue funds, capital project funds, and proprietary funds.  All summary worksheets prepared reflect the information required by the state for Unaudited Actual which are shown on the SACS forms.
A power point presentation highlighting the 2014-15 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.
	 
ESTIMATED ACTUAL vs. UNAUDITED ACTUAL
Each year districts are required to include an estimate of the ending fund balance for each fund with the Budget Adoption process.  It was estimated when the budget was adopted that the general fund ending fund balance would be $36,133,831 and the Unaudited Actual for the general fund totals $41,855,837.  The variance between the estimated actual vs. unaudited actual represents an increase of $5,722,006 to the 2014-15 ending fund balance which has been brought forward into the 2015-16 budget year as an increase to the beginning fund balance for the General Fund.
	 
Board action is requested to approve and accept the 2014-15 Unaudited Actual Financial Report as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and accept the Unaudited Actual for 2014/2015 fiscal year report as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary.

Item:  12.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, and Richard Uribe, Director Adult Education
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve of District Representative and alternate to the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE), Steering Committee as per AB104
		 
I.    Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation.       
		 
For the last two years, the state’s AB86-mandated process initiated the formation of a regional consortium, the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE). The consortium’s membership is composed of five adult schools (East Side Adult Education, Campbell Adult and Community Education, Milpitas Adult School, Santa Clara Adult Education, and Silicon Valley Adult Education) and four colleges (San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College, Mission College and West Valley College).  In March, the SBCAE’s three year plan to address gaps and to align and expand adult education services in the region was submitted to the California Department of Education.  That local plan, one of 71 in the state, informed the state of the consortium plan for adult education and determines the activities of SBCAE for the next three years. 
		 
In June, 2015, the Governor proposed and the Legislature approved an Adult Education Block Grant (AEBG) of dedicated funding.  A “maintenance of effort” funding level was carved out of AEBG that will support K-12 adult education.  Per the June legislation, AB104, additional funding in the 2015-2016 school year, and all AEBG in years following will need to be aligned to the local regional plans, and be approved by a board of consortium members.  
		 
II.   District Administration’s Recommendation
		 
AB104 requires all members to participate in decisions, and calls for publicly-noticed meetings of formal representatives of each member district.   Representatives from each consortium member must be approved by each member’s governance board.   In accordance with AB104, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint Richard Uribe, Director of Adult Education, as primary ESUHSD representative to the Steering Committee of South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE), and Tatiana Roganova, Supervisor of Adult Education, as alternate.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint Richard Uribe, Director of Adult Education, as primary ESUHSD representative to the Steering Committee of South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE), and Tatiana Roganova, Supervisor of Adult Education, as alternate.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Emergency One-Day School Closure for Piedmont Hills High School on August 27, 2015, Due to Water Pipe Rupture
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District is submitting State form J-13A for Board approval.  The District is requesting an attendance allowance to be waived for Piedmont Hills High School.  The one day school closure was due to a main water pipe breakage which left the school with no running water.  The school had taken attendance for the first 60 instructional minutes.  The students were all release approximately by 8:22 a.m. on August 27, 2015.  The attendance was below the statutory minimum day requirement of 180 minutes required by the California Department of Education.
	 
The affidavit and supporting documents, if approved by the County Superintendent, will be forwarded to the School Fiscal Services Division of the California Department of Education. 
	 
A State penalty will apply for not meeting minimum day requirement of 180 minutes.  Also for not meeting the 180 annual school days.  Noncompliance can result in loss of all or portions of state funds.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve submitting Form J-13A the attendance allowance waiver for the emergency "One Day" school closure for Piedmont Hills High School on August 27, 2015.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Farshid Sasami, Program Manager, SGI
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency Distribution 
	 
$48,752,145 of Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency remains unallocated. The Contingency was unallocated because the existing debt service could not support issuance of those bonds without exceeding the Proposition 39 tax rate cap. This is no longer the case, as property values have increased. With the rising cost of construction, together with the District’s unmet facilities needs, it is in the District’s best interest to allocate those funds and use them.
Administration developed three scenarios by which the Contingency may be allocated.
Scenario 1
In this scenario, funds would be allocated to cover specific unmet needs:
Replacement of football field synthetic turf carpet ($4 million): Typically, synthetic turf carpet has a service life of ten years, depending on use. Six out of eleven synthetic turf football fields were installed in 2004/2005 (Andrew P. Hill, James Lick, Oak Grove, Piedmont Hills, Santa Teresa, Yerba Buena High Schools). This funding would allow for replacement of synthetic turf carpet at these six schools.
Construction Cost Escalation contingency ($13 million):  Each of the schools is proceeding with their projects that were Board approved in 2014. Due to current construction market conditions, costs are escalating at a rate reminiscent of the early 21st Century during the dot-com boom.  In order to preserve the base scope of each school’s projects, this contingency set-aside would mitigate extraordinary construction cost escalation.  The monies would be pro-rated to each project’s construction cost and time schedule, the factors impacting cost escalation.  The alternative to providing a cost escalation contingency would be to de-scope projects to stay within budget.
Replacement Music, Art and Administration Building & Central Quad Modernization at W.C. Overfelt High School ($19 million):  W.C. Overfelt is one of Santa Clara County’s underperforming schools.  This improved “front of campus” facility, with next generation learning facilities, will help to retain enrollment and improve student outcomes.  This funding would be an advance to W.C. Overfelt against future bond allocations.
Roofs, Heating/Ventilating/Air Conditioning (HVAC), Electrical Infrastructure ($11.75 million):  There are 48 critical roofs at or beyond their service lives, and current funding for only 7 replacements.  There are over 600 HVAC units at or beyond their service lives, and current funding for only 100.  Of the 13 school sites with aged electrical distribution infrastructure, 5 sites have current funding for total and/or partial replacement.  Replacing roofs, mechanical and electrical infrastructure will ensure the reliability of facilities, increase classroom comfort, and reduce operating costs.  This proposed $11.75 million will not fund all these needs, but will allow replacement of the most critical of these items.
Gymnasium Windows Replacement at Andrew P. Hill High School ($1 million):  Windows in gyms are rare.  The windows at Andrew Hill’s gym lead to increased solar (heat) gain, increasing ventilation costs and thermal discomfort.  The windows are subject to vandalism.  The sun’s ultraviolet rays prematurely degrade the sacrificial finish on the wood floors.  Replacement of the glazing with a fiberglass-based translucent material would mitigate or resolve these issues.
Scenario 2
In this scenario, synthetic turf carpet replacement would be funded ($4 million), and the remaining Contingency would be allocated to school sites, using the 2012 Measure I allocation methodology as a framework for equity ($44.75 million).
Replacement of football field synthetic turf carpet ($4 million)
The remaining Contingency would be allocated to school sites ($44.75 million).
In this scenario, each site would use their additional allocation to cover their construction cost escalation on current projects, and only after having satisfied that requirement could they initiate new projects.  Attachment A delineates the funding distribution for this Scenario 2.
The 2012 Measure I allocation methodology also allocated funds for technology. The 2014 Measure I Technology Bond covers the District’s technology needs, and so a Measure E Board Contingency allocation is not required or included for technology in the funding distribution delineated in Attachment A.
The 2012 Measure I allocation methodology also allocated funds for alternative education.  Alternative education needs are currently being addressed using previously-allocated bond funds, as well as Capital Facilities Fund 25 and School Facilities Fund 35.  The exceptions are Foothill and Phoenix High Schools, for which an appropriate amount of construction cost escalation for their approved projects is indicated in Attachment A.
Scenario 3
This Scenario is a hybrid between Scenarios 1 and 2.  Attachment B delineates the funding distribution for this Scenario 3.
Replacement of football field synthetic turf carpet ($4 million)
Roofs, Heating/Ventilating/Air Conditioning (HVAC), Electrical Infrastructure ($11.75 million)
The remaining Contingency would be allocated to school sites, following Scenario 2’s framework ($33 million).
	 
	 
Administration recommends Scenario 3. Scenario 3’s hybrid approach allows the District to fund synthetic turf and infrastructure needs that are not likely to be identified as priorities through school site facilities planning processes – and yet these items are critical to the continued operation of learning facilities that affect a great population of students and staff. Yet the hybrid approach allocates the majority of Contingency funding to sites so they can first cover the escalating construction costs of their current projects, and then self-determine priorities for any residual funds. This balanced approach satisfies the requirement to provide safe and effective learning facilities while continuing the Board’s methodology of allocating bond funds to school sites using an equity-driven distribution model.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$48,752,145
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E general obligation bond funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the distribution of $48,752,145 of Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency funds in accordance with the Equity Distributions – Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency depicted on Attachment B (Scenario 3).
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the distribution of $48,752,145 of Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency funds in accordance with the Equity Distributions – Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency depicted on Attachment B (Scenario 3).

TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, André Bell,  Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award a Site and Facilities Lease Agreements for Independence High School Building B Commons (Project NO. Z-065-601) Lease Leaseback Construction Project with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc.
			 
On June 19, 2014, the Board awarded a Preconstruction Agreement to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. (McCarthy) to be the Lease Leaseback Developer for the Independence High School Modernization of Building B and Campus Site Improvement Projects (Item 15.03).
			 
Upon approval of the Preconstruction Agreement, McCarthy immediately began implementing components of their Agreement including reviewing the project plans and specifications prepared by Cody Anderson Architects (CAW) for constructability, technical review, value engineering, and obtaining pricing from subcontractors and suppliers to generate a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP).
			 
On June 18, 2015, the Board awarded a Site and Facilities Lease agreement for the interior demolition of Building B in order to be ready for construction upon DSA approval of plans and for the Campus Improvements, (Project No. Z-065-602).
			 
The plans and specifications for the Modernization of Building B now have been approved by DSA.  Staff is now seeking Board approval for the Site and Facilities Lease Agreement to award the Building B reconstruction GMP cost.
			 
To develop the GMP, McCarthy divided the plans and specifications into work categories (WC) or subcontractor trade areas.  McCarthy solicited multiple subcontractors to provide bids for each WC, including firms from the District’s prequalified list of contractors.  McCarthy interviewed the two lowest bid subcontractors for each WC to ensure that their bids contain the full scope and meet the experience and qualification criteria required by the contract documents. McCarthy provided their subcontractor pricing data used to prepare the GMP.
			 
Additionally, in developing the GMP, McCarthy prepared a detailed list of assumptions and clarifications.  Each of these assumptions and clarifications were reviewed and accepted by Facilities staff, CAW and VPCS.  
			 
Through this process of reviewing of the plans and specification for constructability and technical review issues, generating value engineering options and preparing the list of assumptions and clarifications, McCarthy developed their list of Owner contingency items.  This list was reviewed and edited by Facilities staff, VPCS and CAW.  As agreed by McCarthy, the Owner’s Contingency can only be used for a limited list of unforeseen conditions. McCarthy accepts the majority of design risk and unforeseen conditions associated with design conflicts.  McCarthy’s GMP reflects this acceptance of risk. 
			 
Fiscal Impact:
Measure I - $2,477,273.00
Measure G - $794,945.00
Not to Exceed $3,272,218.00
			 
Funding Source:
General Obligation Bond Measure I and G 
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award Site and Facilities Lease Agreements with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., for the Building B (Project No. Z-065-601) Lease Leaseback GMP (Construction) Project, in an amount not to exceed $3,272,218.00 and authorize Administration to execute change orders in accordance with Board Policy 3312.1.

FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and AndrĂŠ Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $25,000
		 
		 
The attached lists the General Purchasing Contracts for Professional Services at or below $25,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
		 
Fiscal Impact:
As presented in the attachment
		 
Funding Source:
As presented in the attachment
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the projects contract(s) for professional services at or below $25,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of August, 2015
		 
		 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of August, 2015, in response to adopted Board Policy 3314 Payment of Goods and Services.  The Policy states that, "The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting."  while there is no legal requirement for Board approval on issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency" of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses.

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

Item:  20.01
					 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
								 
								 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $50,000  
					 
					 
The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
